bestBHT.bht: The disciples, filled with anticipation, stooped and gazed into the open sepulchre but did not enter out of reverential fear. The younger disciple outran the older, seemingly propelled by love's swifter wings. With an air of artless truth, they returned to their own homes, where they reunited with the rest of the disciples. Though their faith may have been uncertain, they believed that Jesus had risen. John hurried to share the glorious news with the mother of Jesus, whom he had taken to his home.

Henry Alford: St. Luke, xxiii. 12, has the very same expression; see there in margin.
This is remarkable, as he evidently has a fragment of the same incident.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: These particulars have a singular air of artless truth about them.
The younger disciple outruns the older; love haply supplying swifter wings.
He stoops, he gazes in, but enters not the open sepulchre, held back probably by a reverential fear.
John Calvin: Their faith was not strong, but was only some confused remembrance of the miracle and resembled a trance, until it was more fully confirmed.
A strong faith could not be produced merely by the sight which they had beheld.
Christ hid himself from them, because they sought him with too great superstition.
Philip Schaff: We are not told why or in what frame of mind they thus returned to their own homes.
One thing is clear: they believed that Jesus was risen.
It was vain to search for Him in the tomb.
Archibald T. Robertson: To themselves." Luke (Luke 24:12) has προς αυτον about Peter ("to his home").
This use of the reflective pronoun for home (literally, "to themselves"), like the French chez eux, occurs in Josephus (Ant. VII. 4, 6).
John had taken the mother of Jesus to his home (John 19:27) and so he now hurried home to tell her the glorious news as he believed.
John Gill: Then the disciples,.... Peter and John, after they had seen and examined things, and satisfied themselves as much as they could."
and so the Arabic and Persic versions; the place from whence they came, and where the rest were assembled together, to pray, converse, and consult together,
they returned to their own company, to the rest of the disciples they left at home, who were as themselves.
John Wesley: They went home — Not seeing what they could do farther.

bhtAttempts.bht: The disciples, in their haste and anticipation, found themselves at the tomb but did not enter. Perhaps held back by a reverential fear, they stooped and gazed in, but did not step inside. Instead, they returned to their own homes, with the younger disciple outrunning the older. This incident has a remarkable and artless air of truth about it, as if love provided swifter wings. John, who had taken the mother of Jesus to his home, hurried back to tell her the glorious news. Though their faith may not have been strong, they believed that Jesus was risen.

The disciples, filled with anticipation, stooped and gazed into the open sepulchre but did not enter out of reverential fear. The younger disciple outran the older, seemingly propelled by love's swifter wings. With an air of artless truth, they returned to their own homes, where they reunited with the rest of the disciples. Though their faith may have been uncertain, they believed that Jesus had risen. John hurried to share the glorious news with the mother of Jesus, whom he had taken to his home.

The disciples, caught in a moment of anticipation, stooped and gazed into the open sepulchre with a reverential fear that held them back from entering. Love seemed to lend swifter wings to the younger disciple, who outran the older. With an air of simplicity and truth, they returned to their own homes, where they joined the rest of the disciples. Though their faith may have been uncertain, they still believed that Jesus had risen. John hurried to his home, eager to share the glorious news with the mother of Jesus.

The disciples, filled with anticipation, approached the tomb but did not enter out of reverential fear. Love seemed to give the younger disciple swifter wings as he outran the older. In an artlessly truthful manner, they returned to their own homes, rejoining the rest of the disciples. Though their faith may have been uncertain, they still believed in Jesus' resurrection. John hurried back to his home, eager to share the glorious news with the mother of Jesus, whom he had taken care of.

The disciples, driven by eager anticipation, stooped and gazed into the open sepulchre but did not enter due to reverential fear. Love propelled the younger disciple to run faster than the older. This incident carries a sense of genuine truthfulness. They returned to their own homes, reuniting with the rest of the disciples. Though their faith may have been uncertain, they held onto the belief that Jesus had risen. John hurried to share the glorious news with the mother of Jesus, whom he had taken to his home.
